description: From Latin crypta (“vault”), from Ancient Greek κρυπτός (kruptós, “hidden”). Doublet of grotto.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A cave or cavern. [from 15th c.]
An underground vault, especially one beneath a church that is used as a burial place. [from 16th c.]
(anatomy) A small pit or cavity in the surface of an organ or other structure. [from 19th c.]
examples: Sometimes, too much foreign material can get caught in the crypts, leading to frequent infections.

entries.meaning: (botany) Any of the genus Cryptocoryne of aquatic plants of southern and southeastern Asia.
(botany) Any of the genus Cryptopus of orchids of Madagascar and Mauritius.
